Award.AwardTitle: Spatially Resolved Nucleosynthesis in Core Collapse Supernovae
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators will simulate exploding stars, called supernovae. They are interested in the nuclear reactions during the explosion. The reactions produce many of the elements on the periodic table. The simulation will model the first second of the explosion and calculate reactions until the expelled material collides with the surrounding region. Existing images of these explosions show that many chemical elements are blown into space. The investigators will compare their models with the existing observations.

The topic of exploding stars captures the public imagination. Through their writing, teaching, and public lectures, the investigators will share this project excitement. They will lead teacher training workshops for Navajo Nation, Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community, and Phoenix inner city schools. The investigators will explain how exploding stars are important for our life on the earth.

The investigators will perform and compare three dimensional (3D) simulations of core collapse supernova explosions and remnant development with the observed spatial distribution of nuclear species in the Cassiopeia A and g292 supernova remnants (SNRs). This is the first opportunity to compare the production and distribution of elements by nuclear burning in 3D explosion simulations directly with well-studied SNRs. Their comparison can provide important constraints on the characteristics of the explosion required to produce a remnant with the observed geometry and abundances, telling us much about both the event itself and the explosion mechanism. Three dimensional smooth particle hydrodynamics explosions of the favored progenitors in realistic environments will be simulated. The spatial distribution be compared with estimates of the spatially resolved abundances derived from the optical, x-ray and infrared observations to constrain the conditions under which nuclear burning occurs.

The production and distribution of heavy elements by supernovae are integral to the evolution of stellar populations and the interstellar medium on scales from individual proto- stellar/proto-planetary systems to galaxies. The project will have impacts in a number of areas beyond nucleosynthesis in supernovae, including numerical methods and massively parallel simulations, turbulent hydrodynamics, stellar and galaxy evolution, astrobiology, and cosmology. This research will integrate research and education by advancing discovery and understanding, while at the same time engaging undergraduates and training graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work examined the connection between the violent supernova explosions that end the lives of massive stars and the synthesis and delivery of chemical elements to the surrounding space, where it contributes to the formation of new stars and planetary systems. It used three-dimensional simulations of supernova explosions from the launch of the blast out to as much as a century after the explosion to see how structures formed in the first few seconds the the stellar core develop on scales of decades and light years.

One key outcome explained a mysterious observation of iron and radioactive 44Ti in the Cassiopeia A supernova remnant by the NuSTAR mission. These sensitive tracers of the explosion mechanism had a very particular distribution that previously could not be explained by models. This work not only explained the observation, but showed that it should be expected from certain kinds of supernovae.

The project also demonstrated that the dynamics of convection in the interior of the progenitor star substantially affect the structure of the resulting explosion. This has been hypothesized for the last decade, but these simulations are the first to quantitatively show the effects.

A systematic survey of the impacts of different sources of asymmetry on the production and distribution of chemical elements was carried out. The contributions of motions in the progenitor star, the explosion itself, the movement of the new-born neutron star, and the instability of material after the explosion control these processes on characteristic scales. These structures can still be seen when the supernova remnant interacts with interstellar gas that may form new stars and planets, strongly influencing the chemical composition of new planetary systems.

By partnering with laboratory scientists studying meteorites, we shed light on the composition of presolar grains found in meteorites. Using 3D simulations of supernovae allows more physically accurate predictions of the composition of dust formed from the debris of the explosion. These models explained ratios found in real supernova dust recovered from meteorites.

This work also provided information on how much radioactive 40K a supernova could deliver to a nearby forming planetary system. This was used to provide initial conditions for simulations of the evolution of exoplanets. The 40K provides long term heating of a planet's interior, so a nearby superova can change how long newly formed planets remain geologically active and how their atmospheres evolve. Similar work provided constraints on how much the abundance of life-essential phosphorus might vary between planetary systems.
